bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, February 24, 1942

div1.p: Truby suggests that Hench visit Russell in order to obtain more information. He notes that the urine entries in the New York Academy notebook are in Neate's handwriting.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, February 24, 1942

opener.dateline:
ALBERT E. TRUBY
145 LAUREL STREET
SAN FRANCISCO, CALIFORNIA
Feb 24/42

div1.p:
The month of February is
on its last legs and still I
have neither seen or heard of
you regarding your promised
trip to the Coast- I have been
hoping to see you and I do hope
that nothing has happened to prevent
your coming- In April or May
I contemplate a trip East and will
probably remain there all through the
summer-

I recieved the copies of the Wyeth
advertisement and your memo. of Feb 3
re the status of the 150 sq. yds of
land you have purchased in Cuba
I have not written on the matter
as I hoped to give you my slant
or the correspondence during your
visit here. I still hold your maps
and photos for the same reason as
I explained in one of my letters-

I practically finished work on
my mms. on Dec. 7th I had just
had the preface typed and about noon that
day was checking it over when
the radio brought the news of the
attack of the Japs on Pearl Harbor.

In Jan. I sent a carbon copy
to my old friend F. F. Russell in
Boston and he still has it. For the
last 3 weeks I have not heard from
him. I imagine he is ill or
very busy- Steward Neate worked under
him for several years in the Army
Medical School Lab. Russell wrote
me that the Lab. book found at the
N. Y. Academy of Med. was shown to him
by Malloch when the latter first purchased
it years ago- He identified Neate's
handwriting in the urine Entries. Russell
is a really great scientific man and
you should try to see him personally
for he may have valuable information
for you-

Please give me a line about
your plans-
